title: Seasons of Collaboration: Funding the ODIN Initiative
summary: Governance efforts in the Cardano ecosystem struggle with healthy collaboration, limiting its ability to deliver transformative, decentralized change.
solution: Guided 12-week program that strengthens Cardano’s governance by teaching practical collaboration, decision-making, and proposal skills—enabling more confident, capable, active on-chain participation.
proposer_relevant_experience:
ODIN has created significant value in the broader web3 ecosystem by fostering human connection, enabling decentralized collaboration, and promoting effective governance principles. Its origins trace back to Catalyst-funded book clubs, which laid foundational ideas. Early collaborations among key organizations like Gimbalabs, Cardano4Climate, and WADA led to the birth of both Andamio and ODIN. ODIN's study and application of S3 governance principles have directly influenced the organizational structures and decision-making processes of entities such as Gimbalabs, Andamio, and multiple Intersect committees and the Intersect Steering Committee, and Constitutional Governance Workstreams.

ODIN serves as a training and proving ground for working in a decentralized manner, where results are the clearest indicator of success. The network is also actively developing methods for direct and fair compensation for contributors, connecting purpose, meaning, and collaboration with the creation of individual value within the Cardano ecosystem and beyond.

ODIN's team makes space for people dedicated to decentralized work. We have defined community roles including our Cultivator (a role facilitating weekly efforts, meetings and coordination) and Harvester (a role focused on gathering the results and enabling reflection and evolution). We will continue defining new roles as needed. Our individuals include:

**Newman Lanier** (see: [https://github\.com/Newman5\)](https://github.com/Newman5)) - background in educational technology and knowledge management, focused on healthy mechanisms of enabling loose coherence between autonomous individuals and groups, so their efforts can be mutually impactful while blending the boundaries and breaking down silos. LinkedIn: ([https://www\.linkedin\.com/in/newman5/\)](https://www.linkedin.com/in/newman5/))

Serves as Cultivator and ODIN treasury trustee.

**Nori Nishigaya** (see: [https://github\.com/xeeban/xeeban\)\)](https://github.com/xeeban/xeeban))) - founder and Zen practitioner, focuses on community management and practicing the fundamentals of collaboration. He brings an integrated perspective from books such as Reinventing Organizations, Brave New Work, Work With Source, and other materials focusing on methods of decentralization and effective collaboration. He is a subject matter expert on Sociocracy, Teal organizations, Agile, and Software Development. He works to cultivate decentralized group cultures to enable trust, clarity, and autonomy. - Builders & educators who want better decision-making structure
- Grassroots Cardano advocates and local community organizers

sub_fields.title: Please describe your proposed solution and how it addresses the problem
sub_fields.description: Please describe your proposed solution and how it addresses the problem
sub_fields.answer:
**Perception of the Problem**

Cardano’s governance processes, while innovative, are currently struggling to translate the ideals of decentralization into consistent, effective collaboration. CIP-1694, the Cardano Constitution, and DRep liquid democracy have created powerful tools, but the human capacity and understanding to use them (see: [https://collaborativesparks\.org/cardano\-gov\-challenges/\)](https://collaborativesparks.org/cardano-gov-challenges/)) lags behind the technical achievements.

We see recurring patterns of unhealthy collaboration: concentration of influence in founding institutions, lobbying and self-dealing in budget processes, and a tendency for governance actions to be driven by a small set of actors rather than the broader community.

These dynamics frustrate contributors, limit diversity of input, and stall truly transformative change. Without deliberate investment in the skills, structures, and shared language of healthy collaboration, governance will limp forward — iterating without clear direction, and missing the chance to inspire and empower the whole ecosystem.

**Reasons for Our Approach**

Season of Collaboration is a 12-week guided learning-by-doing program that builds practical governance and collaboration skills through hands-on practice, pattern-based learning, and structured community facilitation.

Participants learn to:

- process governance tensions
- use Sociocracy and consent-based decision-making
- design and refine proposals
- coordinate across groups
- practice healthy conflict navigation
- participate confidently in Cardano governance

This creates a repeatable pathway from awareness → capability → on-chain participation.



**Why This Works**



ODIN has spent the last three years developing a shared pattern library of collaboration and governance dynamics — used today across Gimbalabs, Andamio, Intersect committees, Xerberus, and grassroots Cardano communities. The Season of Collaboration provides the structure, mentorship, and facilitation to help contributors practice these skills in real community scenarios.



Rather than teaching theory, we train people in the actual substance of collaboration that governance requires.



ODIN’s Season of Collaboration directly targets these gaps by creating a safe, practical, and engaging environment where community members can practice effective collaboration — not just discuss it.



We use a pattern library that names and normalizes common dysfunctions, while offering tested alternatives such as consent-based decision-making, sociocratic peer development, and healthy conflict navigation. This approach works because it doesn’t rely on theoretical training alone — participants learn by doing, week after week, in real interactions that mirror the tensions, diversity, and complexity of Cardano governance itself.



By pairing structured facilitation with open, self-organizing sprints, we foster trust, improve decision quality, and help participants develop actionable proposals that reflect broad, plural input. This method has already proven successful in smaller communities, and scaling it into the Cardano ecosystem will create a culture of collaboration that enables governance processes to function as intended.





**Who We Engage**

- Community hub leaders across regions
- Newcomers seeking a guided pathway into governance
- Teams preparing Catalyst proposals
- DReps & DRep candidates
- Intersect members & working groups
- Governance-focused community contributors
- Builders & educators who want better decision-making structure
- Grassroots Cardano advocates and local community organizers

**Importance to Cardano**

This initiative directly strengthens Cardano’s long-term governance capacity by:

- preparing contributors to participate in on-chain decision-making in Cardano and in decentralized orgs operating on Cardano
- fostering the development of collaborative skills and culture for all Cardano participants including DReps
- lowering the barrier to entry for governance newcomers
- expanding the network of contributors who can be healthy contributors to governance in decentralized orgs
- enabling community groups to coordinate better across regions and factions
- reducing governance bottlenecks caused by fragmentation, conflict, and low confidence

Every funded project in Cardano benefits when participants know how to collaborate effectively. Season of Collaboration makes that capability accessible, trainable, and repeatable across the ecosystem.



**Relevance and Timeliness**

The recent Poison Piggy incident underscored that Cardano’s resilience depends not only on technical robustness but also on the ecosystem’s ability to collaborate effectively under pressure. As highlighted in our accompanying analysis, “What the Poison Piggy Incident Revealed About Cardano’s Human Layer,” ([https://jeremy723866\.substack\.com/p/what\-the\-poison\-piggy\-incident\-revealed\)](https://jeremy723866.substack.com/p/what-the-poison-piggy-incident-revealed)) the recovery depended on shared understanding, rapid decentralized coordination, and trusted communication pathways. Season of Collaboration directly addresses these human-layer challenges by training participants in the real-world governance, facilitation, and collaboration skills that such incidents demand.

sub_fields.title: Please define the positive impact your project will have on the wider Cardano community
sub_fields.description: Please define the positive impact your project will have on the wider Cardano community
sub_fields.answer:
The Season of Collaboration builds capacity within the Cardano community to work together effectively on transformative initiatives. By blending real-time practice, pattern-based learning, and continuous mentorship, we help participants bridge the gap between ideas and implemented, sustainable change.



In the short term, this program delivers:

- Stronger collaboration skills through practical use of Sociocracy, consent-based decision-making, and ODIN’s pattern library
- Action-ready proposals that align with Cardano’s mission and values
- Increased engagement by drawing in diverse participants — from governance contributors to builders, educators, and network stewards



Over time, the cumulative impact grows:

- Participants carry their skills and tools into other Cardano initiatives, multiplying the value of each Season’s investment
- The pattern library becomes a shared memory of what works (and what doesn’t) in decentralized collaboration, lowering the learning curve for new contributors
- Community-led projects are more resilient, transparent, and accountable — making Cardano’s governance and ecosystem more credible to the outside world



Our work recognizes that global change starts with local change. While we may not have direct control over large institutions, we do have influence with the people inside them — and by equipping those people with the skills and structures of healthy collaboration, we seed transformation from the ground up.



Scaling this program will not only expand the reach of these benefits, it will also create a repeatable model that other networks in the Cardano ecosystem can adapt for their own communities, making collaborative excellence a defining feature of Cardano’s culture.



ODIN has been impacting the community in many ways over the years, including:



- MCC
- ICC
- Gov workstreams
- Treasury Guild
- Gimbalabs
- Andamio
- Xerberus

Our team provides verifiable, publicly accessible evidence of governance, collaboration, research, and decentralized coordination capability.

- ODIN Study Groups (CIP-1694, governance,, etc.): [https://drive\.google\.com/drive/folders/1eq6ktSinCTmHiIzppp6y3eDZeR8sOER0?usp=sharing](https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1eq6ktSinCTmHiIzppp6y3eDZeR8sOER0?usp=sharing)
- Leadership Book Clubs & governance training ecosystem (Reinventing Organizations, Work With Source. Etc since 2022): [https://www\.youtube\.com/playlist?list=PLYueNF0lzhQ1cYjJ8DYvenOiSrOplS4Pb](https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLYueNF0lzhQ1cYjJ8DYvenOiSrOplS4Pb)  [https://www\.youtube\.com/playlist?list=PLYueNF0lzhQ380Pg0oXd761foGHASzoXb](https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLYueNF0lzhQ380Pg0oXd761foGHASzoXb)
- Season of Collaboration pilot results: [https://docs\.google\.com/document/d/1Xt0vwSKElNf1RfHublTrTtcljzclwilL8oZ\-TXHh\-3s/edit?usp=sharing](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1Xt0vwSKElNf1RfHublTrTtcljzclwilL8oZ-TXHh-3s/edit?usp=sharing)

**Impact to Date**

Our methodologies, patterns, and facilitation practices influence:

- Intersect Steering Committee
- Membership & Community Committee (MCC)
- Constitutional Governance Workstreams
- Gimbalabs
- Andamio
- Photrek R&D
- Xerberus governance model and open standards development
- SugularityNet Ambassador's Program

ODIN’s approach blends governance theory with practical, embodied skill-building — the missing layer needed for decentralization to function at scale.

**Pathway to Adoption \(Required Category Section\)**

Target On-Chain Actions

Our program prepares participants for five main types of on-chain activities::

1. Enable mission-aligned groups to progress from collaborative practice into on-chain actions such as contribution recognition, incentive flows, governance signaling, and tokenomics engagement.
2. Develop direct audiences for onchain transactions in ODIN's s3 governance app; and between project owners, Odin staff and collaborators
3. Participating in Intersect, Ecosystem or Constitutional governance workflows
4. Enabling informed representative governance through skilled delegation and the cultivation of capable, collaboration-trained DReps.
5. Open and developing channels for Cardano community members to participate in groups seeking more liquid capital, creating opportunities for Cardano holders to be leveraging their holdings with impactful Cardano based ventures

Pathway to Adoption

1. Join collaborative spaces
2. Contributors enter ODIN’s practice sessions, working groups, and community collaboration environments.
3. Develop shared intentions & governance literacy
4. Using S3 patterns and ODIN facilitation, groups learn alignment building, tension processing, and participatory decision-making.
5. Engage in structured, incentivized collaboration
6. Governance working groups and S3 processes help teams navigate roles, responsibilities, and value creation.
7. Form governance-ready groups around real work
8. As contributors coordinate effectively, they become stable groups capable of authentic governance participation.
9. Activate purpose-driven on-chain behaviors
10. Groups begin using on-chain tools for:
11. contribution recognition
12. incentive flows
13. project governance signals
14. tokenomics-based engagement
15. Expand on-chain adoption through aligned missions
16. Cardano holders engage not just as speculators but as active participants backing missions and ventures they trust.

This creates a repeatable, scalable pipeline from ecosystem engagement → governance literacy → active on-chain participation.

sub_fields.title: How does the cost of the project represent value for the Cardano ecosystem?
sub_fields.description: How does the cost of the project represent value for the Cardano ecosystem?
sub_fields.answer:
This project gives the treasury a high-leverage investment in the long-term success of Cardano governance and community-led innovation.



**Strengthens Governance Capacity**

- CIP-1694 and the Cardano Constitution create the rules, but healthy governance requires the skills and culture to work well within them.
- Season of Collaboration turns governance theory into practical, repeatable skills, producing contributors who are better prepared to design, evaluate, and implement governance actions.



**Increases the Return on All Funded Projects**

- Many Catalyst-funded projects fail to achieve transformative impact, not because of poor ideas, but because teams lack the collaboration, decision-making, and feedback structures to execute impactful efforts effectively.
- By training and mentoring participants before and during their projects, we reduce waste, improve delivery rates, and ensure that good ideas don’t die in execution.



**Delivers a Reusable Asset to the Ecosystem**

- The ODIN pattern library and program framework become a shared infrastructure for collaboration, available to all Cardano projects and future Seasons without needing to start from scratch.
- This creates ongoing value beyond the funding period — each future participant benefits from the cumulative learning of previous cohorts.



**Demonstrates Tangible Impact**

- Through measurable KPIs (proposals developed, skills adopted, cross-team collaborations formed), Catalyst will get hard data on how this investment directly strengthens the ecosystem.
- Our reporting and documentation will show not only what was achieved, but how the skills learned in the Season ripple outward into other Cardano initiatives.



**Builds Cultural Resilience**

- Healthy, skilled collaboration reduces factionalism, lobbying dominance, and burnout — all threats to decentralized governance.
- Investing in the people and the culture creates a stable, adaptable foundation for the community to thrive through future challenges.



In short: The treasury gets more than a 3-month program — it will be invested in the people, patterns, and practices that will make every other funded initiative more effective, aligned, and resilient.



**Recognition & Endorsements**



Our Fund 14 governance proposal received strong endorsements from:

- A Cardano Foundation governance contributor curating high-impact governance proposals: [https://forum\.cardano\.org/t/fund\-14\-assessments\-through\-a\-governance\-lens/149644](https://forum.cardano.org/t/fund-14-assessments-through-a-governance-lens/149644)
- Multiple governance educators and DReps
    - [https://forum\.cardano\.org/t/distributed\-decision\-making\-list\-of\-proposals\-endorsed\-by\-rodrigo/149613/4](https://forum.cardano.org/t/distributed-decision-making-list-of-proposals-endorsed-by-rodrigo/149613/4)
    - [https://x\.com/RodrigoPacini/status/1971654093874884788](https://x.com/RodrigoPacini/status/1971654093874884788)



These endorsements praised the clarity, rigor, and real-world utility of our pattern-based governance framework.
